attachments.title: IBM-Blockchain/fabric-boilerplate
attachments.text: fabric-boilerplate - Get up and running quickly with your own blockchain application!

text: <@U3LH9V41L>  I've seen this where people are trying to use the v0.6 branch of the code and then are following the instructions in the v0.6 branch of the documentation, but....get twisted up because there are a couple spots in this doc where it has a wget (for the chaincode) and a git clone (for getting the fabric code available locally in order to build the chaincode) that refer to *master*.   The problem is, that *master* is now v1.0 code.    So, they are running Docker images with v0.6 code but when they build the chaincode locally, it incorporates v1.0 code in into it.   The solution is, in the *wget* and the *git clone*,  change *master* to *v0.6* in the path name.   I am being purposely vague as to where this documentation is, because if I've guessed correctly, you know what I'm referring to, but if I've guessed wrong, it's something else and I don't want to lead you on a wild goose chase.   I hope this helps.
Thank you <@U0YJUECE8> . I will try clone new example.
Wow, problem solved. I checkout chaincode v0.6, everything work like magic.
can i create table with multiple keys and make query with a specific one or more ??

<@U3VKNAAQH> if you are referring to the Table API in Fabric v0.6,  you can create multiple keys but you can only access by keys in left-to-right order.  That is,  if your key columns are defined as A B C D   you can query against,  A,  or against A B,  or against A B C,   or against A B C D only.   You can't, for example, query against B  or against A C  (skipping B), etc.

<@U3VKNAAQH> richer functionality is definitely in place for v1.0 but I can't articulate the details... but check out dave.enyeart's msg in <#C0YPYBVJM|fabric-dev> from 6:48 am just this morning and he talks about using JSON in chaincode instead of tables....that might be of interest, and, I think that channel might also be a better place to ask if you have further questions on this subject.
